abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Second National
            Environmental Project of Brazil were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Lessons learned from this
            project included: (a) the reaffirmation of the viability of
            a decentralized approach to environmental management. By
            transferring decisions and implementation down to the State
            level, the Federal Government was able to accomplish several
            important goals: (1) leverage policy and regulatory change
            at the State level; (2) generate enthusiasm, energy and
            counterpart funding for state selected priorities; (3) build
            capacity for environmental management at the State level;
            (b) even in a nominally decentralized system, there may be
            some resistance by central government (i.e. Ministry of
            Finance) to allow decentralized decision making. Often this
            resistance comes indirectly in the form of fiscal controls;
            (c) the importance of building an effective communications
            component into the project in that success of a project may
            often depend on its capacity to identify key stakeholders
            and to communicate with them effectively, in both
            directions; (d) the lack of a comprehensive baseline to
            measure actual improvements in environmental quality through
            the implementation of subprojects at the state level is an
            important lesson from Second National Environmental Project;
            (e) the delays encountered in the signing of contracts owing
            to slow administrative procedures by UNDP: Ministry of
            Finance has relied on UNDP as a service provider for letting
            contracts, which often experienced delays affecting project
            implementation; and (f) the flexible methodology provided by
            Ministry of Finance for determining the State's
            environmental priorities which was often not closely
            monitored and which opened the door to arbitrary decisions.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Environmental Project is the
            first phase of the Second National Environmental Program
            which seeks to improve environmental quality in priority
            areas by increasing the effectiveness of environmental
            institutions at local, state, and national levels in Brazil.
            The project will focus on institutional strengthening, i.e.,
            monitoring, licensing, and coastal zone management (CZM) and
            the identification and prioritization of environmental
            problems. It will strengthen decentralized environmental
            management at a State and municipal level through two
            components: 1) institutional strengthening and 2)
            environmental assets. The institutional strengthening
            component will support innovative activities to strengthen
            and improve licensing procedures at a state level; improve
            State-level water quality monitoring systems by financing
            the upgrading of existing monitoring systems or installing
            new monitoring systems in water basins where there are
            actual or potential conflicts in water use; and support CZM
            of up to 15 coastal states. 2) The environmental assets
            component will provide technical assistance to States to
            support a participatory process of priority-setting and the
            adoption of improved policies and other measures to achieve
            the priorities identified.
